white power march in charlottesville

americans into the workforce so
we're really pleased to have ken frazier

thanks it's great to be here um so let's
dive right in
um there are four black ceos
in the fortune 500 now by my account you
are among them
why is that number still so woefully low
and how does that change
well i have to say that i think that the
reason the number is so low
is that we haven't yet gotten past
some of the uh
perspectives i will say uh that our
society has around
the capabilities of african americans um
as you watch all of these companies they
have
great statements about diversity i
believe that they
they want to do the right thing but we
live in a world in which people are
swimming in this sea
of past beliefs and perspectives and
they don't work to the advantage of
african americans and so
i think what has happened in corporate
america is with respect to
women for example we've been very
intentional about
putting more women on boards and getting
more women into senior management
when when the issue comes to blacks or
african-americans
i think those are harder issues they
tend to raise
concerns or are we lowering the
standards are we
adopting quotas um the fact of the
matter is i think for
for african americans uh in all walks of
life they still have to overcome
a series of stereotypes that often are
had about african americans and their
capabilities so
i think that goes a lot to it i think
you know in this country
african americans do face opportunity
gaps
in terms of education um they do face
when they get into corporate america
they do face access gaps
in terms of having the kinds of close
relationships with the kinds of people
in the senior management who could make
or break careers in my
example i was very fortunate that i was
hired by a former ceo
to work directly for him and and and
actually on my best day
i'm actually recycling and re-channeling
the things that i learned from our very
close working relationship
that kind of access is very unusual for
african americans
so ken when we last when you and i last
spoke in 2017
you talked about how even with your
educational and professional pedigree
you had to learn and i'm using your
phrase you had to learn how to become
user friendly
in the nearly all-white world in which
you work so
let's you started to talk about how
things are today but you know the murder
of george floyd
has helped make this the issue of
diversity of priority in boardrooms
across the country there's a lot of talk
you know in your view has anything
tangible come out of all the talk at
this point
i think it's too early to reach a
conclusion about that what i am very
optimistic about is i think
after the murder of george floyd it did
create a moment
in this country where people both at
boardroom tables as well as kitchen
tables at home
began to ask ourselves questions about
our country
and the disparity that exists between
our stated creeds on the one hand
and how we actually function in this
country so
i do think that while it's too early i'm
optimistic
the initiative we're going to talk about
in a few minutes is an example of
corporate leaders coming together saying
that we're going to really make a
difference as it relates to the
employment of black americans
as i mentioned you broke with president
trump in 2017 after the
the charlotte's after the
charlottesville incident um
that was courageous then i mean you were
you were about the first ceo to
to kind of take that step you know now
business people are abandoning trump in
droves it's sort of safer to do so but
i gotta ask i mean when you look at what
happened in washington last week
what are you thinking and and what's the
right approach for ceos
to this moment so i will start by saying
that i see what happened in washington
as sort of a logical bookend to what
happened in charlottesville
uh in charlottesville what we had were
armed
militias so to speak made up of
neo-fascists
white supremacists descending on
charlotteville charlottesville
outnumbering the police
in that situation i think following that
unfortunately we didn't make strong
statements the president made statements
that were at best equivocal i think they
were heard
uh by some of the people who were among
those armed militias as being
supportive if not glorifying them
and i think if you think about it you
saw the same thing happen in state
capitals you know people
armed people took over the capitals in
idaho and oregon
and michigan you might remember in
michigan there was this concept that
they might kidnap in and harm the
governor of michigan because the
mask mandates so in some ways
what happened in the capital was sort of
the logical
um outcome of what we've tolerated and i
think that what we have to remember as a
society
is that while i hope we'll move towards
unity and healing
in the next few years we can't tolerate
certain types of behavior violence and
destruction
no matter what the cause behind it is is
not acceptable
and what is also not acceptable is
telling lies about things that are
important to our society
and so uh i think all of us have to be
willing to take a stand
for civil discourse in our society
for truthful discourse in our society
and against violence because
if we don't these kinds of things are
going to keep happening
so i'm going to ask one more question
and then bring in my co-host who i know
want to
ask you more about about 110 and more
about a lot of things but
i want to switch gears a little bit and
talk about merck
and the pharma industry you know you
were i would say relatively pessimistic
about the pace of developing a vaccine
for covet 19
and i think it's fair to say the
relatively optimistic timetable
prevailed so
what has surprised you in terms of the
rollout of the initial vaccines
well i have to say that first of all the
initial vaccines that have rolled out
are fantastic
vaccines um the the first couple of
vaccines in moderna and the pfizer
biontech vaccines
have um an efficacy level that is way
beyond i think anyone's wildest dreams
uh i think we see that the mrna vaccine
platform was one that was amenable to
quick
quick uh adoption i i think it turns out
if you look at the other vaccines that
are coming along
it turns out that the spike protein
itself seems to be highly immunogenic
so there's hope for that there'll be
more vaccines beyond the first couple of
vaccines
but i think the very good news is that
we have vaccines that have set a very
high bar
in terms of efficacy and i you know the
challenge now
it's obviously distributing them and
making sure that we get beyond the most
vulnerable people
and get them out to the public as at
large but i think it's very good news i
think it's very hopeful
and i think it underscores the
importance of an industry that is
invested in lots of different
technologies including in the case of
mlrna
fairly new technologies that proved out
to be very useful in this context
i mean you know it seems like we were
capable of something that
would earlier have seemed impossible you
know
before these vaccines you know merck is
very much involved in the vaccine
business the fastest vaccine ever
developed was four years of the months
vaccine but this new technology
as i said is amenable to faster
development at merc we're very much
focused now given
the success of a lot of those early
vaccines you know while we still have
two vaccine programs
uh that we're that we're undertaking
we're really also focused on
therapeutics uh that is to say
the kinds of therapeutics oral
therapeutics that can be used
for people who are early in the disease
process that can hopefully knock down
the virus
and make it less transmissible as well
as vaccine
pardon me as well as therapeutics that
could be used fairly late in the disease
in the disease process where people are
actually having real problems with the
breathing the people who are in the icus
who have huge
inflammation issues we're working very
hard on the kinds of therapeutics that
we hope will bring to the market in the
next few months
that actually help people who are
already infected
all right so let me let me bring in my
my co-host and
octavia probably uh over to you uh for
the next question
and so ken one ten's mission is focused
on black americans
who do not yet have a four-year degree
studies have shown that black men have
the lowest completion rates among
students enrolled in four-year public
institutions and
you talked about the opportunity gaps in
education in your opinion what's the
most
consequential systemic barrier that's
preventing black students from
completing their degrees
well that's a very complicated question
i mean we start from this
from the premise that nearly 80 of black
americans at age 26 do not have a
four-year degree
i think one of the big barriers is a
financial one
uh you know people who come from
families who don't have
access to to funds who don't know how to
get those funds
actually do not get their education even
though they start them i mean i saw a
piece of data recently about community
colleges that says that something like
75 percent of the people who start in
community colleges
never complete even an associate's
degree or a two-year degree
so i think the financial barrier is
probably one of the most significant
ones as it relates to the completion of
four-year degrees so one tense coalition
represents
the largest ever private sector-led
mobilization of its type
you've raised more than 100 million
dollars in seed funding you have a
strikingly clear
10-year goal how will progress be
measured
and how will you hold the firms that
have committed their support
accountable so let me start by saying
yeah we do have i think
very important measurable goals setting
a goal of
1 million black americans who are higher
and these are
black americans who otherwise would not
have been hired and we can talk about
how we're going to think about that
going forward but the goal really is
for companies to start with a baseline
every company
has to look at where it is already on
its journey around diversity
and after they're able to do that then
we'll develop plans that are based on
where
each company is today so that they can
move forward and this is not just about
the 37 companies
it's about their suppliers it's about
others that we can bring in if we're
going to hire a million
black americans over 10 years it's not
going to be just
these 37 companies so you know this is
not about
you know the government for example
holding us accountable or any outside
organization
these companies that put up this 100
million dollars in first year
c funding they're committed to doing
something different
that in terms of improving how they
train hire uh promote
african americans so
i want to talk a little bit more about
that retention and also the economic gap
that you referred to earlier and bring
gender into the mix
um women continue to earn less than men
and this disparity is even more
pronounced for women of color we are the
most
underrepresented group in the corporate
pipeline we are hired at lower rates we
are promoted at lower rates we're
retained at lower rates
we're paid at lower rates how can ceos
fix this
well i think again i we have to be
intentional about it so a few years ago
inside merck
we looked around and said you know there
are not many women in operating roles
around the world and we decided that we
wanted to be very intentional about
trying to focus on those those
disparities and so you know people began
to mentor
the senior women or the women coming
through the pipeline who
could reasonably aspire to be in these
jobs
uh and as a result over about a 10-year
period we went from having almost no
women
in these senior jobs to having 40 of
these jobs
occupied by women i think we haven't
done the same kind of thing we haven't
had the same kind of intentionality
around african americans and in
particular as you point out
african-american women and so i think a
big part of this is
examining what we've been doing now we
can't keep doing the things that we've
done now and expect a very different
outcome
so this is really about being
intentional focusing on that group
uh ensuring that you know people have
sponsors and mentors
you know i'm sitting in the ceo chair
because i was sponsored by my
predecessor three times removed uh and
most people don't have that kind of
access
and so we want to make sure that people
are being very thoughtful about that
i'll just make the point about the
wealth gap because you know
recent data show that the average
african american family
has a net worth of 5 000 where the
average white family has a net worth of
that's a staggering staggering
difference and
it has to do with an intergenerational
cycle
of of poverty of lack of
opportunity and that's what we're trying
to address at 1
10. we we're really trying to address uh
those systemic barriers that have
existed in this country
uh that have prevented african americans
from having access to earned success and
the american dream
okay i'm gonna um i'm still

just mentioned ken because that's

the act the average employed
african-american
man today in 2021
has a bigger gap versus his male white
counterpart
and i'm acknowledging the point about
women in my
my comparison here the gap is as big as

so from a societal standpoint we are
making
no progress with respect to
incorporating
african americans into the economic
mainstream
at a time when the workforce itself is

so as a country if we don't figure out
how to get the benefit of all of
our talent and we know that the
education to employment pipeline
particularly fails
african americans if we don't address
that
i don't see how corporations can
possibly be successful
and by the way if we do address it these
people become
customers they buy our products they
don't become simply people
who have to be sustained through a
social welfare system so
there's no reason for us not to take on
this as a society i'm sorry
no no no i appreciate that thank you um

ask their questions uh because we do

i want to follow up on the vaccine a

a couple of things that i'm curious
about one is that the government was
involved
deeply in funding for a company not just
the us government but governments
and i'm curious is this just a crisis
and a one-off or are we actually seeing
different models for business and
government working together towards
innovation
i hope it's the beginning of different
models first of all there are a lot of
companies that didn't accept government
funding for example pfizer bayern tech
did it all
from their internal capital but i think
that what we see here
is the government's saying look how do
we
create sustainable models for people to
go after these kinds of
uh viral and bacterial infections and
you know we've walked right up to that
in the past so for example after 9 a
lesbian
and after 9 11 the government was very
much worried about bioterrorism
and it said okay let's make sure that
these companies have the funding to
develop
the kinds of protections against
bioterrorism but somehow we forgot about
that
i'll use the example about antibiotics
and you know
in 2050 more people will die from
resistant forms of bacteria
than will die from cancer and yet we
don't have a market
that actually supports work we don't
have market-based initiatives
so we have to find these public-private
partnerships
in order to provide the capital to go
after things
uh like we did in the example of covid
so i would hope
that we would continue to focus on those
kinds of issues
because it's unlikely that this is going
to be the last viral pandemic we face
well we faced ebola before this
we've now faced this we face sars we
first
we face mirrors we have to continue to
develop the kinds of
medicines and vaccines that we need and
and
you know we had uh there were
difficulties with some of those diseases
to get vaccines that could be successful
some some false starts and some some big
problems and in some cases
but now we've seen that we can get to
market so quickly with the vaccine and
you talked about that and the new
technology
is that something generally that is the
public we can expect that
as we see different types of diseases
come along we're going to be
able to move much faster or is that this
particular situation
generally speaking i think we should be
optimistic that we can move a lot faster
with some of the new technologies and
some of the things that we've learned
but we have to realize that each virus
is very different
so for example we still don't have a
vaccine for hiv
we've been going after that now for
decades and we haven't been able to
develop a vaccine that works for that
particular virus because of
among other things it mutates so quickly
i think in this
instance one of the things that we see
and i mentioned it earlier is the
particular spike
protein for sars cov2 which causes cobit
itself is extremely immunogenic and you
can see that
because other companies using very
different platforms from the mrna
vaccine for example johnson and johnson
just had data out today about their
adenovirus vaccine
they're seeing high levels of
immunogenicity based on
different platforms that use if you will
despite protein
as the anagen so i think we should be
optimistic going forward
that some of these new technologies will
allow us to come forward with vaccines
much quicker
but we have to recognize that there is a
unique
aspect of the spike protein for covid19
that makes it uh not easier to develop a
vaccine but makes the vaccine much more
immunogenic
and you talked about the therapeutics i
know merck has just
recently invested big time uh with an
acquisition
which just makes me think we're going to
be living with cobit for a long time
if a company if you're going out if
you're going to invest
in these therapeutics and so this is
we're not
seeing this is not going to be
eradicated basically no i think that if
you look at the natural history of viral
infections very rarely if any
have we seen be eliminated or eradicated
so you know what we're hoping to do is
to get through this pandemic phase
uh where we have you know large numbers
of people being sick
and dying but there will still be an
endemic phase where we're going to have
to think about the right kinds of
vaccines
and the right kinds of therapeutics for
people who get sick and remember
something about this particular pandemic
it is truly a global pandemic
ebola where we were very fortunate in
developing a vaccine here at merck
turned out not to be really a global
pandemic it turned out to be
a pandemic that was really confined to
certain countries in sub-saharan africa
this is now truly a global platform uh
or a global disease and i like to say
until all of us are safe none of us are
safe
yep so ken i'd like to bring in some
questions that we've received in real
time
from our audience and the first one is
from brandon
who's in washington dc and brandon says
as an employee of ge healthcare
and an operating leader of its african
american forum
what advice would you offer in terms of
how i can influence
our ceo larry kopp to sign on to this
critical initiative well
you can bring it to his attention that's
the first thing
i think that what we have inside these
organizations with
organizations like the one that you lead
inside ge
is when when people come together for
example black
employees and really believe in their
own
agency they can bring issues to their
management
management has to obviously decide
whether to join the coalition or not
ge is a great company it has a great
workforce
and i think the only thing you can do is
urge your management to take it
seriously and to look at this very
seriously and i know i'd be happy to
talk to larry kopp
i'd be very happy to talk to my former
colleague who's your general counsel
mike holston and others
uh if this is the right time for ge to
join i think that would be a good thing
but i think it needs advocacy
inside the company so brenda from
maryland has a question about the
measurement and evaluation process for
she'd love to know will public updates
be made
i expect that public updates will be
made but i you know we haven't started
there we really started
with the position that companies have to
assess where they are each company is in
a different place and by the way
each one of these companies has on its
own journey done some really good things
along the lines of how to hire train and
promote
african americans uh what we're really
trying to do right now is
is look internally so i i mentioned the
fact that
80 percent of african americans at age
26 don't have a four-year degree
so the first step is for these companies
to look internally at their own
job requisitions and to ask which of
these jobs
really do require a four-year degree
we're really saying we have to adopt a
skills first
hiring approach rather than a
credentials based
uh hiring approach and so i don't know
that we're actually
company by company deciding whether each
company will make
its progress public what we want to do
is hold 110 the startup company that
we're creating
and it is a startup and it's intended to
actually
help connect the employer community
with the companies and non-profits and
credentialing organizations that train
people which exist and some of them do a
very good job but they're sub-scale
uh what we're trying to do is to bring
the collective power of these companies
together
by offering jobs and then that will help
people on the other end the people who
are actually
training and developing people to be
able to do it at scale
and so 110 will hold itself accountable
over time
to how close we are getting to the goal
of 1 million
black americans being hired over 10
years
so we have another question from lance
in illinois
as a corporate leader how do you wade
through
the various political spectrums in a
highly charged landscape
and not create party lines when
challenging systemic norms
within your company walls that's an
excellent question it's not an easy
question i will say first of all i don't
believe
as the ceo of merck i have the right to
tell people what to think about partisan
political issues and i try to avoid
taking
positions on partisan political issues i
don't know that my employees would
always agree that i'm successful
but what i try to address with my
platform
or what i consider to be issues that go
to our values as a com
country so when i speak out about
something like charlottesville for
example
i tried very hard not to make it a
partisan issue i thought what was going
on in charlottesville really spoke to
the
companies excuse me to the country's
core values
and so what i really do with 110 i think
americans
all agree that we want to have economic
opportunity and it should be available
to everyone
and so when we started this it was
really more about saying
how could we actually vindicate the
aspiration that we have in our society
of
everyone having an equal opportunity by
addressing the
systemic barrier that these four-year
job requirements had on a group of
people who disproportionately have not
had
access to that so
we were just talking about the role of
the ceo um
when political issues come up and you
know you made it clear the bar has to be
pretty pretty high
for you at least to kind of wade in on
these issues so i'm interested
you know charlottesville was a moment
when you were out there
and and relatively alone initially
what was the fallout in terms of
business in terms of
employee response customer response i
mean
it was their fallout for for taking a
public stance
you know against the president back in
so there was public fallout i i would
point out that before i did that i
actually consulted my board because
i wanted to make sure that the board was
comfortable that i was speaking both
based on my own personal conscience as
well as as ceo of merck and i'm very
pleased that my board you
said unanimously we want you to speak to
the company's values but there was
fallout
there were some customers who were
unhappy with us uh there were employees
inside the company
who viewed my uh my statement to the
public as being
against the president i was really
saying
these are our values as a country we
believe in
pluralism we believe in equality and
i think our leaders need to make
statements against
bigotry and hatred unfortunately some
people viewed that as being
against the president that was not my
goal by the way
just to flip it around when the
president asked me to join
his business council many of my friends
on the opposite side of the political
spectrum criticized me for that
they said oh you're now supporting the
president
my view was as the ceo of merck if the
president of the united states wanted to
have
our input on issues that are important
like health care
that i ought to show up in the room
because i was asked and when i joined
initially i
i was willing to take the criticism of
my more
left oriented friends and when i stepped
off i was willing to take the criticism
of my own more right oriented friends
so i know we're going to run out of time
here but i i'm really interested to know
